tit.cmt: 穴師坐兵主神社の読み方が確立していないようです。ウエブでは「あなしにます・・」となっていたためこれを採用しました。原文のように「せにます・・」は他では「せにいます・・」となっていました。

sen.j: 穴師坐兵主神社（あなせにますひょうずじんじゃ）は、奈良県桜井市にある神社である。
sen.e: Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture.
Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture.
Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 式内社で、旧社格は県社。
sen.e: This shrine is a Shikinai-sha (a shrine listed in Engishiki ["Engishiki" is an ancient book for lows and regulation compiled during the Engi Period, in which shrine listing procedures are included]), designated as a prefectural shrine in the old shrine ranking.

It is a shikinai-sha (a shrine listed in the Engishiki [an ancient book of laws and regulations compiled during the Engi era listing shrines]), and designated a prefectural shrine according to the old shrine ranking system.

It is a shikinai-sha (a shrine listed in the Engishiki [an ancient book of laws and regulations compiled during the Engi era listing shrines]), and designated a prefectural shrine according to the old shrine ranking system.

sen.j: 元は穴師坐兵主神社（名神大社）、巻向坐若御魂神社（式内大社）、穴師大兵主神社（式内小社）の3社で、室町時代に合祀された。
sen.e: Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine (Myojin-taisha Shrine [shrine enshrining deities under the ritsuryo system]), Makimukunimasu-Wakamitama-jinja Shrine (Shikinai-taisha Shrine [first-ranked shrine listed in Engishiki laws]) and Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine (Shikinai-taisha Shrine) were enshrined together in the Muromachi period to be the current Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine.

It is comprised of Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine (Myojin-taisha Shrine [shrine enshrining deities under the ritsuryo system]), Makimukunimasu-Wakamitama-jinja Shrine (Shikinai-taisha Shrine [first-ranked shrine listed in Engishiki laws]) and Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine (Shikinai-taisha Shrine) which were merged during the Muromachi period to form the current Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine.

It is comprised of Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine (Myojin-taisha Shrine [shrine enshrining deities under the ritsuryo system]), Makimukunimasu-Wakamitama-jinja Shrine (Shikinai-taisha Shrine [first-ranked shrine listed in Engishiki laws]) and Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine (Shikinai-taisha Shrine) which were merged during the Muromachi period to form the current Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 現鎮座地は穴師大兵主神社のあった場所である。
sen.e: The site where the shrine is now standing was that of Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine.
The site where the shrine now stands was that of Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine.
The site where the shrine now stands was that of Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 元の穴師坐兵主神社は、垂仁天皇2年に倭姫命が天皇の御膳の守護神として祀ったともいわれる。
sen.e: There is a theory that the old Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine was enshrined by Yamatohime-no-mikoto in B.C.28 as a guardian deity of meal presented to the emperor.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: There is a theory that the original Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine was founded by Yamatohime-no-mikoto in the year 28 BC enshrining a guardian deity of food presented to the emperor.
There is a theory that the original Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine was founded by Yamatohime-no-mikoto in the year 28 BC enshrining a guardian deity of food presented to the emperor.

sen.j: 景行天皇が八千矛神（大国主）を兵主大神として祀ったともいう。
sen.e: Moreover, another theory suggests that the old Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine was enshrined by the Emperor Keiko for worshiping Yachihoko-no-kami (other name of Okuninushi [chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan]) with the name of Hyozu-no-okami.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Another theory suggests that it was founded by the Emperor Keiko for worshiping Yachihoko-no-kami (other name of Okuninushi [chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan]) under the name Hyozu-no-okami.

Another theory suggests that it was founded by the Emperor Keiko for worshiping Yachihoko-no-kami (other name of Okuninushi [chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan]) under the name Hyozu-no-okami.

sen.j: 旧鎮座地は「弓月岳」である。
sen.e: The old shrine is believed to have been in 'Mt. Yutsukigatake.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The old shrine is believed to have been at 'Mt. Yutsukigatake.'
The old shrine is believed to have been at 'Mt. Yutsukigatake.'

sen.j: 比定地には竜王山・穴師山・巻向山の3つの説がある。
sen.e: As for the question of which mountain 'Mt. Yutsukigatake' indicates, there are three controversial presumed sites of Mt. Ryuo, Mt. Anashi and Mt. Makimuku.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: There are three theories that 'Mt. Yutsukigatake' refers to one of Mt. Ryuo, Mt. Anashi or Mt. Makimuku.
There are three theories that 'Mt. Yutsukigatake' refers to one of Mt. Ryuo, Mt. Anashi or Mt. Makimuku.

sen.j: 祭神の「兵主神」は現在は中殿に祀られ、鏡を神体とする。
sen.e: Hyozu-no-kami,' the enshrined deity of the old Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine is now enshrined in the center hall of the current Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine, while respecting a mirror as Shintai (object of worship housed in a Shinto shrine and believed to contain the spirit of a deity).

Hyozu-no-kami,' the enshrined deity of the old Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine is now enshrined in the central hall of the current Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine, and the shintai (object of worship housed in a Shinto shrine and believed to contain the spirit of a deity) is a mirror.

Hyozu-no-kami,' the enshrined deity of the old Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine is now enshrined in the central hall of the current Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine, and the shintai (object of worship housed in a Shinto shrine and believed to contain the spirit of a deity) is a mirror.

sen.j: 神社側では兵主神は御食津神であるとしている。
sen.e: The current Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine has supported the theory regarding Miketsukami (the God of Food) as Hyozu-no-kami.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The current Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine maintains that Hyozu-no-kami is Miketsukami (god of food).
The current Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine maintains that Hyozu-no-kami is Miketsukami (god of food).

sen.j: しかし他にアメノウズメ、スサノオ、天富貴命、建御名方命、大国主の分身の伊豆戈命、国魂とする説がある。
sen.e: However, there are other theories regarding other deities such as Amenouzume, Susano (Deity in Japanese Mythology), Amanotomimuchi-no-mikoto, Takeminakata-no-kami, Izuhoko-no-mikoto or the double of Okuninushi, Kunitama as Hyozu-no-kami.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。分身の訳がわかりません。
sen.e: However, there are other theories that Hyozu-no-kami is another deity such as Amenouzume, Susano (deity in Japanese mythology), Amanotomimuchi-no-mikoto, Takeminakata-no-kami, Izuhoko-no-mikoto (the spiritual emanation of Okuninushi), or Kunitama.

However, there are other theories that Hyozu-no-kami is another deity such as Amenouzume, Susano (deity in Japanese mythology), Amanotomimuchi-no-mikoto, Takeminakata-no-kami, Izuhoko-no-mikoto (the spiritual emanation of Okuninushi), or Kunitama.

sen.j: 巻向坐若御魂神社の祭神「若御魂神」はクシナダヒメのことであるとされる。
sen.e: Kushinadahime is identified with 'Wakamitama-no-kami,' the enshrined deity of Makimukunimasu-Wakamitama-jinja Shrine.
Kushinadahime is identified with 'Wakamitama-no-kami,' the enshrined deity of Makimukunimasu-Wakamitama-jinja Shrine.
Kushinadahime is identified with 'Wakamitama-no-kami,' the enshrined deity of Makimukunimasu-Wakamitama-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 現在は右社に祀られ、勾玉と鈴を神体とする。
sen.e: It is now enshrined in the right hall of the current Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine, while respecting Magadama (a comma-shaped bead) and a bell as Shintai.
It is now enshrined in the right hall of the current Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine, and the shintai is a magadama (a comma-shaped bead).
It is now enshrined in the right hall of the current Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine, and the shintai is a magadama (a comma-shaped bead) and a bell.

sen.j: 元は巻向山中にあった。
sen.e: The shrine was originally located in Mt. Makimuku.
The shrine was originally located at Mt. Makimuku.
The shrine was originally located at Mt. Makimuku.

sen.j: 若御魂神については、ワクムスビのことであるとする説もある。
sen.e: There is another theory advocating that Wakamitama-no-kami indicates Wakumusubi.
There is another theory advocating that Wakamitama-no-kami indicates Wakumusubi.
There is another theory advocating that Wakamitama-no-kami indicates Wakumusubi.

sen.j: 上記の2社は、『正倉院文書』に天平2年（730年）に神祭を行った記録があり、貞観 (日本)元年（859年）に従五位の神階が授けられた。
sen.e: According to "Shosoin Monjo" (document collection of the Nara period kept in Shosoin), the above-mentioned two shrines held a festival to honor deities in 730, conferred the divine rank of Junior Fifth Rank in 859.

According to "Shosoin Monjo" (document collection of the Nara period kept in Shosoin), the above-mentioned two shrines held a festival to honor deities in 730, and were conferred the divine rank of Junior Fifth Rank in 859.

According to "Shosoin Monjo" (document collection of the Nara period kept in Shosoin), the above-mentioned two shrines held a festival to honor deities in 730, and were conferred the divine rank of Junior Fifth Rank in 859.

sen.j: 穴師大兵主神社については鎮座年代は不詳である。
sen.e: It is uncertain when Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine was enshrined.
It is uncertain when Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine was founded.
It is uncertain when Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine was founded.

sen.j: 祭神の「大兵主神」は現在は左社に祀られ、剣を神体とする。
sen.e: Daihyozu-no-kami,' the enshrined deity of Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine is now enshrined in the left hall of the current Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine, while respecting a sword as Shintai.
Daihyozu-no-kami,' the enshrined deity of Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine is now enshrined in the left hall of the current Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine, and the shintai is a sword.
Daihyozu-no-kami,' the enshrined deity of Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine is now enshrined in the left hall of the current Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine, and the shintai is a sword.

sen.j: 大兵主神の正体については、八千戈命（大国主）、素盞嗚命、天鈿女命、天日槍命という説がある。
sen.e: As for the question of who is enshrined as Daihyozu-no-kami, Yachihoko-no-kami Okuninushi), Susano-no-mikoto, Ame-no-uzume (one of the female gods in Japanese mythology) and Amenohiboko-no-mikoto are regarded as the most likely candidate.

As for the question of which deity is enshrined as Daihyozu-no-kami, Yachihoko-no-kami Okuninushi), Susano-no-mikoto, Ame-no-uzume (one of the female gods in Japanese mythology) and Amenohiboko-no-mikoto are regarded as the most likely candidates.

As for the question of which deity is enshrined as Daihyozu-no-kami, Yachihoko-no-kami Okuninushi), Susano-no-mikoto, Ame-no-uzume (one of the female gods in Japanese mythology) and Amenohiboko-no-mikoto are regarded as the most likely candidates.

sen.j: 中世ごろから、穴師坐兵主神社が穴師上社、穴師大兵主神社が穴師下社と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: From around the Medieval period, Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine was called Anashi-kamisha Shrine (literally, upper Anashi-jinja Shrine), while Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine was called Anashi-shimosha Shrine (literally, lower Anashi-jinja Shrine).

From around the Medieval period, Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine was called Anashi-kamisha Shrine (literally, upper Anashi-jinja Shrine), while Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine was called Anashi-shimosha Shrine (literally, lower Anashi-jinja Shrine).

From around the Medieval period, Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine was called Anashi-kamisha Shrine (literally, upper Anashi-jinja Shrine), while Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine was called Anashi-shimosha Shrine (literally, lower Anashi-jinja Shrine).

sen.j: 応仁の乱のときに若御魂神社と穴師上社の社殿が焼失したことから、この2社を穴師下社（大兵主神社）に合祀した。
sen.e: After Makimukunimasu-Wakamitama-jinja Shrine and Anashi-kamisha Shrine were burned down in the Onin War, these two shrines were merged with Anashi-shimosha Shrine (Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine).
sen.cmt: 原文では若御魂神社，大兵主神社と略されていますが，似た言葉が頻出します。混乱を避けるために訳文では正式名で書きました。
sen.e: After Makimukunimasu-Wakamitama-jinja Shrine and Anashi-kamisha Shrine were burned down in the Onin War, these two shrines were merged with Anashi-shimosha Shrine (Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine).
After Makimukunimasu-Wakamitama-jinja Shrine and Anashi-kamisha Shrine were burned down in the Onin War, these two shrines were merged with Anashi-shimosha Shrine (Anashi-Daihyozu-jinja Shrine).

sen.j: 明治6年（1873年）に郷社に列し、昭和3年（1928年）に県社に昇格した。
sen.e: Designated as a village shrine in 1873, Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine was promoted to a prefectural shrine in 1928.
Designated as a village shrine in 1873, Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine was promoted to a prefectural shrine in 1928.
Designated as a village shrine in 1873, Anashinimasu-Hyozu-jinja Shrine was promoted to a prefectural shrine in 1928.

sen.j: 摂社として、野見宿禰を祀る相撲神社があり、相撲の祖神として信仰されている。
sen.e: Sumo-jinja Shrine enshrining NOMI-no-Sukune, who is believed as the Soshin (ancestor honored as god) of Sumo (Japanese-style wrestling), is an auxiliary shrine.
Sumo-jinja Shrine enshrining NOMI no Sukune, who is believed to be the Soshin (ancestor honored as god) of sumo wrestling, is an auxiliary shrine.
Sumo-jinja Shrine enshrining NOMI no Sukune, who is believed to be the Soshin (ancestor honored as god) of sumo wrestling, is an auxiliary shrine.
